div1.p: Carter discusses ways to modify a pond in order to minimize mosquito infestation.

div1.head: Memorandum by Henry Rose Carter, [19--]
div1.p:

N. M. C
Mid West
Mountain
Island

(This was for the Mountain Island Project - to be installed
on the Catawba.)

MEMORANDUM
for
Preparing Area for - a Pond.

item.p: (1) Cutting Brush and Trees.

Cutting all brush from just above the flowage contour- say 25' hor- '2'L
to a little below the lowest contour at which the pond will stand.

Brush must be cut so far below this contour that it
will (a) either not project above below thethe low level of the water or
(b) by some ways -25' to 30' - from the bank.

All Pine trees, and saplings growing in groups close to-
gether, should be cut as brush except that all Pine trees should be cut which
project above the water; no matter how far they are from the bank.
Pine needles are bad floatage.

Hardwood trees out in the pond are of little importance. It may be
advisable to cut them but it scarcely necessary.

There is no advantage in cutting anything which will
always be covered by water or in cutting hardwood cut in the pond.
(2) Removal of Things Cut.

Remove or burn completely all the logs: branches etc.,
of the stuff cut on the pond. It is not a bad plan when the pond
is filling and any stuff overlooked is floating ashore to haul it
out. This is the easiest way to remove logs as they will float
up to the bank. & save will be over-looked in a large pond,
Insert par: 2' see - same S. P. Co
(3)Bulrushes.

Where there is a growth of bulrushes on the edges
of the pond which will stick out of the water, they will not die,
and they furnish excellent protection to mosquitoes against fish.
These should be grubbed up with a hoe, and thrown above pond level.
This is a smaller job than it seems as it will only need to be
done about the heads of a very few bights. On the Bridge-water
lake, a survey of probably 12 miles of bank only showed two places
needing it. Whether cutting bulrushes close to the ground, so
that they would be entirely covered wit by water for some months,
will kill them or not I do not know. It is worth trying as an ex-
periment.
(4) BURNING THE FLOWING AREA.

Burn over the flowing area or as much as possible of it
and as late as you can before filling the pond - generally - during
the early winter before. This is to get the deagd grass, leaves,
etc. off the ground. This is not always possible,
(5) SPROUTS.

The stumps of saplings and brush cut down for the pond
will in many cases send up a lot of sprouts. These that grow on
the edge of the pond, from the flowage contour to below the minimum
level, should be cut again just before the pond is filled. If the
water stays above the cut stumps few - I think no - sprouts will
start again. This is very important.

This was for a large pond
for which the preperation would n-e-
guine 2 to 4 years
(5) FISH.

Make arrangements for stocking the pond with fish so
that they may be inabundance while it is being filled and as soon
as it is filled. The Alabama Power Company, at the instance of
Mr. LePrince has done this for their pond under construction at Lock
#8 on the Coosa, so that when the water rises the minnows (Gambusia)
will be let out in the pond.

You can get information on this from Mr. Thurlow,
Alabama Power Company, Birmingham, or information and assistance by
appkying to Surgeon L. D. Fricks, U. S. Public Health Service, Room
17, Court House Building, Memphis, Tenn., asking him if he could let
you have assistance in this matter of Mr. J. A. LePrince or Mr.
Hildebrand. There would be no charge for the service of either of
these men.
(7) POOLS.

Where it is obvious that a fall of the pond will leave
pools of water in hollows in the ground which will last over two
weeks, ditches should be cut which would empty them.

I confess that I have seen little Anopheles production
from this cause, (a) because such depressions holding water for the
two weeks necessary for Anopheles production have not been common,
(b) because fish are usually left in such pools as the water goes
down. They, the pool, are more common on flat banks than steep
- 3 -
ones. This work can economically be left and is generally
left until the pond is full and falls and then these pools may
be easily seen. They must be attended to however - either be-
fore or after the pond is filled.
(8) AFFECT OF THESE MEASURES ON BREEDING.

This is about all that is necessary or advisable to
be done to the flowage area for the prevention of malaria, and I am
sorry to say that this will not prevent it entirely. All the large
ponds I have seen constructed in a country in which Anopheles quad.
can breed, have eliminated some breeding places and made others and
the balance between the benefit and injury produced depends to an
extent upon the balance between them. Generally for the first two
or three years, at any rate, the injury has been greater than the
benefit, although not always. The above measures however, will
unquestionably minimize the production of Anopheles.
(9) FLUCTUATION OF THE POND.

Of at least as much, probably of greater, importance
in preventing Anopheles production, than the preparation of the
flowage area, is the provision for fluctuation of the levels of
the pond. The idea is to keep it as high as possible in the
non-breeding season - Nov. 1st to June 15th or July 1st here -
and lower during the breeding season the remainder of the year o
and during the breeding season to fluctuate as much as practical;
saving every rise of the river and running your water off between
the rises.

This was for Charlotte N. C.
You one for-the-south

A slight fluctuation is a little value; 1' to 2' and
3' is of much and once in two weeks is often enough to change.
(10) EFFECT OF TIME.

In generally, the first 2 or 3 years of the pond is
the worst for malaria. Frequently it gets better from the first
year. After that the banks become cleaner and the fish more
numerous and naturally both the wave-action and the fish-control
less inen the production of Anopheles.

div1.p:
Of the end result of large ponds on the incidence of
malaria I have not had an opportunity of studing a sufficient
number to advise you.

The growth of aquatic plants should become consider-
able; giving protection to Anopheles larvae. The upper reaches of
the pond itself should shoal and become more or less marshy. The
lower parts of creeks emptying into the pond might also fill up
causing them, the creeks, to overflow more easily and making the
drainage of their valleys more difficult. This would be especially
apt to occur if the creek carries much sand - indeed in the sand-
carrying creeks it frequently occurs without any pond.

In 1921 at the instance of General Beach, Chief of
U. S. Engineers, I wrote a memorandum on this same subject for
use in the preparation of the large pools, of which his corps has
supervision; Muscle Shoals was the immediate consideration. This
although brief is naturally better systemized than the foregoing
and I will send it to you when I reach Washington.

The best time to fill the pond, in this section, would
be in October - say October 15th or later if need be. This is too
late for A. quad., the species which especially breeds in ponds, to
breed to as to do any harm that year and before the beginning of
their breeding season the next year - say June 15th to 30th. Most
of the small trash and flotage would be stranded or sunk and the
grasses at the water edge dead and worn away.

This was for
Charlotte & for a big pond,

The worst time would be in early summer, May or June
for reasons the reverse of those given above.
